lexUnit.name: bleat.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: speak or complain in a weak or foolish way.

sentence.text: ` I 'm not a salesman , " Grimwood bleated .
` Oh ! " she bleated , her voice high and rather indignant .
` Are you sure that thing is dead ? " bleated Frye .
` But I 've only just got here , " bleated Stitch .
` No , " bleated Bastide , finding some kind of voice .
He even bleats that she did n't want to have sex with him when they were married .
As revelations about the freebie hols followed , he bleated that he was the ` victim " of a tabloid newspaper war .
` He bleats that his critics are talking the country down .
Bank after bank bleated to John about a sudden dearth of cash in the Stevenson account .
` I am no fan of my muscles , " she bleated to a German magazine .
` Do n't bleat to me about fairness , " he rasped , his tone suddenly harsh .
PETER REID last night told the rest of English football to stop bleating about Blackburn 's spend , spend , spend policy .
Typical of the government 's hypocrisy , in Pink 's view , that it could bleat about the failure of exporters while at the same time putting every sort of obstacle in their path .
Reid , preparing for today 's confrontation at Ewood Park , declared : ` Blackburn have made it harder for the rest of us but there is no point in bleating about it .
When federalists bleat on about how interdependent the world is , one wonders what world they live in .
Stuart 's been bleating on about how I changed my name , has n't he ?
It 's no good just bleating on about the rising tide of crime to get money out of the government .
Is n't that right , Mr Didier ? " he almost bleated .
